oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Orpheum Theatre Presents Forty Days a King
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small flyer advertising the showing of "Forty Days a King," the coronation festivities of George V of Great Britain, presented by the Kinemacolor Company in America. There is a photograph of the Coronation carriage.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Announcements; Handbills; Theaters; Motion picture industry; Motion pictures; Short films; Kings; Coronations
Broadsides; Motion pictures; George V, King of Great Britain, 1865-1936
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Kinemacolor was the first successful color motion picture process, used commercially from 1908 to 1914. It was invented by George Albert Smith of Brighton, England in 1906 and launched by Charles Urban's Urban Trading Co. of London in 1908. George V became King-Emperor (Emperor of India) in 1910 on the death of his father, Edward VII. The film was made in 1911.
